VOL. XXX, No. 17
NEW LACROSSE SCHEDULE
SHOWS IMPORTANT
CHANGES
Navy, Lehigh, and Mt. Washington Do
Not Appear. Vacancies Filled By
St. John's And Army

Revisions of a very notable character are to be found in the recently released 1926 lacrosse
schedule. The absence of Lehigh,
Navy, and Mt. Washington, hitherto considered among the most
formidable of the old schedule, is
the most glaring of all the omissions.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 1, 1925.

0. D. K. INITIATION AT
ASSEMBLY THURSDAY
The Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa will hold
a public initiation at the Assembly Thursday.
The private initiation and
banquet will take place that
evening at the Rennert.
Dr. Charles Leber will be
the speaker of the day. Dr.
Leber, it will be remembered,
was the speaker at the initiation last spring. Dr. Leber
was a member Of the society
when an undergraduate, and
was one the best cheer leaders ever to lead a Hullaballoo.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 1, 1925.

HOPKINS FOOTBALL
Well, the team did the trick. Facing tremendous odds.
with the betting five to one against them, they went in and
outplayed, outgamed, and outfought, etc., etc., etc., ( there are
many more phrases easily swiped from the rosy-hued columns
of the city's dailies, but we refrain,)---they outfought old Maryland, and came out with another moral victory (obnoxious
phrase). There was much surprise at the result of the game.
but much more surprise at the smallness of the crowd.
Starr Mathews, writing in the A i»crican. attributes the size
of the crowd to the Hopkins' schedule. He says that our habil
of playing nonentities from other States leads the Baltimore
public to ignore our team. He suggests a schedule comprised
of State teams only, and predicts a large attendance at the
games with these institutions. A sort of Maryland Conference, is the gist of his article.
.
The NEWS-LETTER shakes in its shoes when it ventures to
contradict Mr. W. R. Hearst's highly paid sporting expert. He
should, and probably does, "know his oats" when sports are in
quesiton. Nevertheless, we disagree.
It is true that a little more interest might be aroused by
games with Western Maryland, Mt. St. Mary's, Washington,
and perhaps Loyola. It is admitted, however, that the athletic
•code of some of these institutions is rather lax, and this is the
first objection to such contests. And in the second place, we
do not believe that the Baltimore public will patronize Hopkins games, or, for that matter, the games of any other State
college, with any degree of interest, no matter who is the opponent. Baltimoreans are not interested in their own institutions; half of the population think that the Hopkins' teams
are composed of doctors and medical students; they are ignorant of the existence of any other department of the University.
,This apathy to home institutions will always keep the crowds
down to a small size.
For the same reason that Baltimore could not support big
league baseball, for the same reaison that_it_does not _support
any first-class teams in any sport,—for that reason, whatever
it is, it will not flock to Hopkins' football games, no matter
how high a brand of sport is presented.
This, in short, is why we differ with the learned Mr.
Mathews. And we believe that it is better to play gentlemen
from out-State colleges than gentlemen from in-State schools
with no reputation.
However, to be constructively critical, we would suggest
games with teams of the class of Virginia, Washington and
Lee, Swarthmore, and North Carolina. Better to lose to men,
than to win from babies and sucklings.

WE POINT WITH PRIDE

Black and Blue Jay Staff, who put out the November number
of their publication on the twenty-sixth day of the month.

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS

LITERATURE COMPOSED WHILE YOU WAIT
The editor wants us to be more literary. More literary
and less controversial regarding campus affairs.
The master has spoken; besides, we believe that he is about
right. Truly, this column is not suffering from too much literary flavor.
•
Unfortunately, however, we don't know just what the
editor is talking about. There seems to be literature and literature.
It is quite likely that thiscolumn is neither one nor the
other. We, too, have a feeling that Yes and No is not always
garbed in immortal phraseology.
Nevertheless, to be literary, one must be literary about
something. And we have rather enjoyed being "literary" about
,collegiate affairs.
Perhaps the fact that they are easy to write about has led
us to give too much space to them. There is so much disagreement about the conditions at Hopkins that Yes and No is sure
to agree perfectly with the feelings and thoughts of someone, and so be literature for that person.
Of course, there remain other things to be eloquent about.
It may be that the editor wants us to be literary about literature.
That is not so difficult as it sounds. Granted that we
may not know literature when we see it, such is also the case
with many of our readers.
A large part of the art of being considered literary consists in the mere act of writing about writing. The only discretion required is in the choosing of books which the readers
cannot b'e certain are not "literature."
An even more impressive gesture is to print in the column
a few bizarre, insane or empty poems, and to accompany them
with serious remarks. In order that we may carry out this
program, Yes and No is hereby thrown open to short contributions of literary pretensions.
Our preliminary remarks have been over long, we fear.
We really must get down to being literary.
In the absence of contributions, we are forced to be serious
about one of our own poems. It should certainly live up to
the above-mentioned specifications: we wrote it in our Freshman year.
Moreover, we wrote it at a so-called white heat. We had
just finished reading some poems; we felt immeasurably stirred;
and we wrote!
It is easy to be serious about this immortal verse. Indeed,
it is little less than sad to ponder over the depths achieved by
the Soul of a Freshman when throbbing with the Divine Afflatus. '
ESCAPE
Rushing madly, wildly onward,
Never pausing to consider,
• Never stopping to look backward,
Fearing that the slightest falt'ring
Would cause all my hopes to vanish,
To outdistance my ambitions;
Knowing only that my pleasure,
All my joy of living, loving,
Lie in trampling down my doubtings,
Overwhelming protestations,
In confounding all conventions.

Throughout 'the colleges and
universities of the country student polls are being held in an
effort to determine the student
opinion on the World Court question. This question will occupy
an important part of the program
of the United States Senate when
it next convenes, and for this reason, there has been much interest evinced in it. The poll, which
was organized by the New Student, is now on in six hundred..
and fifty colleges and universities. Its object is to band too-ether the students in American
colleges in an endeavor to use the
strength of the opinions expressed
to bring about the entry of the
United States into the World
Court.

The Haverford News recently
expressed the indignation of the
student body against "rank commercialism" in football. So many
Haverford men have suffered injuries at the hands of teams employing paid athletes that they
almost fail to recognize football

•

as a "game" any longer. Faculty
resolutions claim that the college
"does not pay athletes to attend
Haverford. However, they do that
which is probably worse in throwing a light team against the crushing physical power of great universities in order to cash in on a
few gate receipts." The athletic
authorities are now facing the possibilities of either buying husky
athletes to play on Haverford
teams, or stop stacking her teams
against odds.

A movement is being made at
Rutgers University to create a
memorial to Dr. William V. Leggett. Dr. Leggett was captain of
Rutgers' first team in their first
game in 1869 with Princeton.
This was the first game ever
played between two colleges.

SHIRT DISPUTES
OF BAND SETTLED
At a previous meeting of
the student'activ,ities council,
leader Gorsuch, of the band,
complained of a sale of jerseys to the band by the A.
A. Board. Gorsuch contended the jerseys were too expensive and were of poor material, which soon began to
tear.
The council investigated
the complaint and found the
sale to have been satisfactory
and the jerseys in good condition when delivered.
The Omicron Delta Kappa
society also investigated, and
reported the sale to have been
satisfactory.

Revisions of a very notable character are to be found in the recently released 1926 lacrosse
schedule. The absence of Lehigh,
Navy, and Mt. Washington, hitherto considered among the most
formidable of the old schedule, is
the most glaring of all the omissions.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 1, 1925.

0. D. K. INITIATION AT
ASSEMBLY THURSDAY
The Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa will hold
a public initiation at the Assembly Thursday.
The private initiation and
banquet will take place that
evening at the Rennert.
Dr. Charles Leber will be
the speaker of the day. Dr.
Leber, it will be remembered,
was the speaker at the initiation last spring. Dr. Leber
was a member Of the society
when an undergraduate, and
was one the best cheer leaders ever to lead a Hullaballoo.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 1, 1925.

HOPKINS FOOTBALL
Well, the team did the trick. Facing tremendous odds.
with the betting five to one against them, they went in and
outplayed, outgamed, and outfought, etc., etc., etc., ( there are
many more phrases easily swiped from the rosy-hued columns
of the city's dailies, but we refrain,)---they outfought old Maryland, and came out with another moral victory (obnoxious
phrase). There was much surprise at the result of the game.
but much more surprise at the smallness of the crowd.
Starr Mathews, writing in the A i»crican. attributes the size
of the crowd to the Hopkins' schedule. He says that our habil
of playing nonentities from other States leads the Baltimore
public to ignore our team. He suggests a schedule comprised
of State teams only, and predicts a large attendance at the
games with these institutions. A sort of Maryland Conference, is the gist of his article.
.
The NEWS-LETTER shakes in its shoes when it ventures to
contradict Mr. W. R. Hearst's highly paid sporting expert. He
should, and probably does, "know his oats" when sports are in
quesiton. Nevertheless, we disagree.
It is true that a little more interest might be aroused by
games with Western Maryland, Mt. St. Mary's, Washington,
and perhaps Loyola. It is admitted, however, that the athletic
•code of some of these institutions is rather lax, and this is the
first objection to such contests. And in the second place, we
do not believe that the Baltimore public will patronize Hopkins games, or, for that matter, the games of any other State
college, with any degree of interest, no matter who is the opponent. Baltimoreans are not interested in their own institutions; half of the population think that the Hopkins' teams
are composed of doctors and medical students; they are ignorant of the existence of any other department of the University.
,This apathy to home institutions will always keep the crowds
down to a small size.
For the same reason that Baltimore could not support big
league baseball, for the same reaison that_it_does not _support
any first-class teams in any sport,—for that reason, whatever
it is, it will not flock to Hopkins' football games, no matter
how high a brand of sport is presented.
This, in short, is why we differ with the learned Mr.
Mathews. And we believe that it is better to play gentlemen
from out-State colleges than gentlemen from in-State schools
with no reputation.
However, to be constructively critical, we would suggest
games with teams of the class of Virginia, Washington and
Lee, Swarthmore, and North Carolina. Better to lose to men,
than to win from babies and sucklings.

LITERATURE COMPOSED WHILE YOU WAIT
The editor wants us to be more literary. More literary
and less controversial regarding campus affairs.
The master has spoken; besides, we believe that he is about
right. Truly, this column is not suffering from too much literary flavor.
•
Unfortunately, however, we don't know just what the
editor is talking about. There seems to be literature and literature.
It is quite likely that thiscolumn is neither one nor the
other. We, too, have a feeling that Yes and No is not always
garbed in immortal phraseology.
Nevertheless, to be literary, one must be literary about
something. And we have rather enjoyed being "literary" about
,collegiate affairs.
Perhaps the fact that they are easy to write about has led
us to give too much space to them. There is so much disagreement about the conditions at Hopkins that Yes and No is sure
to agree perfectly with the feelings and thoughts of someone, and so be literature for that person.
Of course, there remain other things to be eloquent about.
It may be that the editor wants us to be literary about literature.
That is not so difficult as it sounds. Granted that we
may not know literature when we see it, such is also the case
with many of our readers.
A large part of the art of being considered literary consists in the mere act of writing about writing. The only discretion required is in the choosing of books which the readers
cannot b'e certain are not "literature."
An even more impressive gesture is to print in the column
a few bizarre, insane or empty poems, and to accompany them
with serious remarks. In order that we may carry out this
program, Yes and No is hereby thrown open to short contributions of literary pretensions.
Our preliminary remarks have been over long, we fear.
We really must get down to being literary.
In the absence of contributions, we are forced to be serious
about one of our own poems. It should certainly live up to
the above-mentioned specifications: we wrote it in our Freshman year.
Moreover, we wrote it at a so-called white heat. We had
just finished reading some poems; we felt immeasurably stirred;
and we wrote!
It is easy to be serious about this immortal verse. Indeed,
it is little less than sad to ponder over the depths achieved by
the Soul of a Freshman when throbbing with the Divine Afflatus. '
ESCAPE
Rushing madly, wildly onward,
Never pausing to consider,
• Never stopping to look backward,
Fearing that the slightest falt'ring
Would cause all my hopes to vanish,
To outdistance my ambitions;
Knowing only that my pleasure,
All my joy of living, loving,
Lie in trampling down my doubtings,
Overwhelming protestations,
In confounding all conventions.

Throughout 'the colleges and
universities of the country student polls are being held in an
effort to determine the student
opinion on the World Court question. This question will occupy
an important part of the program
of the United States Senate when
it next convenes, and for this reason, there has been much interest evinced in it. The poll, which
was organized by the New Student, is now on in six hundred..
and fifty colleges and universities. Its object is to band too-ether the students in American
colleges in an endeavor to use the
strength of the opinions expressed
to bring about the entry of the
United States into the World
Court.
